title: Ali Wong looks back on her miscarriage as she covers new issue of Health
text:
Ali Wong has revealed why 'no topic is off limits' when it comes to her comedy.

The 37-year-old covered the new issue of Health and discussed her onstage candor with the magazine.

She shared that when she put her miscarriage in her act: 'I remember hoping my husband’s parents wouldn’t be disappointed. It was this intrinsic concern.'

No holds barred: Ali Wong feels 'no topic is off limits - it just depends if I can make it funny'

Ali said: 'I didn’t want them to feel like their son married a bad seed - and they didn’t feel that way; they were very supportive.'

She clarified: 'And there was nothing that would indicate that they would ever think that way, but that’s where my mind immediately went.'

Ali, who married tech executive Justin Hakuta in 2014, recorded Netflix stand-up specials during both of her pregnancies.

Letting it out: The 37-year-old comedian covered the new issue of Health and discussed her onstage candor with the magazine

'It was this intrinsic concern': She shared that when she put her miscarriage in her act: 'I remember hoping my husband’s parents wouldn’t be disappointed'

When the first of them, Baby Cobra, made her a star: 'I was shocked nobody was trying to talk to me about my gender or my race, which I loved. Everyone wanted to talk about me being pregnant and how I spoke about my miscarriage.'

During the Baby Cobra miscarriage bit, she joked: 'Don't feel bad, okay? They were the size of poppy seeds. I've picked boogers larger than the twins that I lost.'

While discussing the subject with Health, Ali shared that she had already told her loved ones she was pregnant when she miscarried.

Lucky: Ali said: 'I didn’t want them to feel like their son married a bad seed - and they didn’t feel that way; they were very supportive'

Looking back: She clarified: 'And there was nothing that would indicate that they would ever think that way, but that’s where my mind immediately went'

'I didn’t realize miscarrying was a thing that could happen. That’s why I told everybody. I told the lady who cleans my house, and when she found out I was seven weeks along, she told me I shouldn’t be telling people,' she said.

'Now I know why. It’s because then you have to tell everyone the bad news. Some people have insensitive reactions. Like, they will ask if it’s because you had sushi or you were performing too much. They want to point to some cause and don’t realize how bad that makes you feel,' Ali remembered.

When it comes to material: 'I’ll let my husband veto stuff. It’s not so much about subject choice; it’s about word choice. So no topic is off-limits - it just depends on if I can make it funny. I would love to talk about politics, but I’ve never been able to craft my thoughts into jokes rather than just share anger.'
